categories.name: AI and Technology
categories.description: Tweets related to artificial intelligence, machine learning, coding, and emerging technologies.
examples: This tweet discusses the core mechanism of o3, an AI model, which seems to involve searching for and executing natural language programs within a token space during inference.

This tweet announces a new AI system that can automate tasks within the Chrome web browser. The AI achieved an impressive score of 90.5% on the WebVoyager benchmark, which tests an AI's ability to complete complex web-based tasks like booking flights.
This tweet introduces a new technique called 'Plan Like a Graph (PLaG)' for improving the performance of large language models without fine-tuning.

subcategories.name: AI Models
subcategories.description: Tweets about specific AI models, their development, and capabilities.

subcategories.name: Coding and Development
subcategories.description: Tweets related to programming, software development, and coding tools.

subcategories.name: Emerging Technologies
subcategories.description: Tweets discussing new and innovative technologies beyond AI.

categories.name: Business and Entrepreneurship
categories.description: Tweets related to startups, business strategies, marketing, and entrepreneurial ventures.
examples: This tweet discusses how a startup intern built a custom AI invoice processor in just 2 hours using Gumloop, a no-code AI platform, instead of paying a consultant $16,000 for the same task.
This tweet promotes a video by @YifanBTH that provides guidance on setting up an effective rules file, likely related to cybersecurity or system administration.
This tweet highlights the influential role of a small group of individuals in driving technological advancements and shaping the tech culture.

subcategories.name: Startups
subcategories.description: Tweets about startup companies, their products, and entrepreneurial journeys.

subcategories.name: Marketing and Sales
subcategories.description: Tweets related to marketing strategies, sales techniques, and customer acquisition.

subcategories.name: Business Strategies
subcategories.description: Tweets discussing business models, growth strategies, and industry trends.

categories.name: Personal Growth and Mindset
categories.description: Tweets focused on self-improvement, mindset shifts, and personal development.
examples: This tweet expresses the author's intention to include a simulation program that generates smooth random noise in the terminal, with implementations written in C, C++, and Python programming languages, to their project called 'smolorg'.

This tweet discusses how advancements in measurement tools allow us to detect signals emitted by physical objects, specifically mentioning that damaged ceramic insulators on transmission wires emit radio frequency (RF) signals.

This tweet reflects on the author's past approach to self-improvement and personal growth, which was characterized by an authoritarian and coercive mindset, until they discovered the teachings of Alan Watts around 2015.

subcategories.name: Mindset and Motivation
subcategories.description: Tweets about cultivating a positive mindset, overcoming challenges, and staying motivated.

subcategories.name: Productivity and Habits
subcategories.description: Tweets related to productivity techniques, habit formation, and time management.

subcategories.name: Self-Improvement
subcategories.description: Tweets focused on personal growth, self-discovery, and self-actualization.

categories.name: Science and Research
categories.description: Tweets discussing scientific discoveries, research findings, and academic topics.
examples: This tweet highlights a significant breakthrough in material science where a neural network trained on physical simulation data successfully predicted an emergent crystal structure, which was completely outside of its training data distribution.
This tweet discusses a mathematical approach to solving a Poisson-like equation on vector fields using discrete exterior calculus.
This tweet announces a new research paper that studies the scaling laws for precision in quantizing large language models like BitNet and Llama-3, both during pre-training and post-training.

subcategories.name: Scientific Discoveries
subcategories.description: Tweets about new scientific findings, breakthroughs, and advancements.

subcategories.name: Academic Research
subcategories.description: Tweets related to academic research, papers, and scholarly topics.

subcategories.name: Emerging Fields
subcategories.description: Tweets discussing new and emerging areas of scientific exploration.

categories.name: Creative Arts and Design
categories.description: Tweets related to creative pursuits, art, design, and artistic expression.
examples: This tweet showcases the creative application of combining MediaPipe, a framework for building cross-platform machine learning solutions, with stream diffusion, a technique for generating images.
This tweet announces a new 3D character rig created by the author in Blender. The rig features a beetle-like wing structure on the back that opens up, revealing hidden thrusters underneath.
This tweet criticizes the trend of people requesting design files or templates instead of learning how to recreate designs themselves.

subcategories.name: Visual Arts
subcategories.description: Tweets about painting, drawing, sculpture, and other visual art forms.

subcategories.name: Design
subcategories.description: Tweets related to graphic design, user interface design, and design principles.

subcategories.name: Digital Art
subcategories.description: Tweets focused on digital art, animation, and creative coding.

categories.name: Social Commentary and Perspectives
categories.description: Tweets expressing opinions, social commentary, and unique perspectives on various topics.
examples: This tweet expresses a cynical view that most wealthy individuals acquire their riches through unethical or illegal means, referring to them as 'scamming' and calling them 'rats'.
This tweet critiques the idea of viewing oneself as a problem that needs to be solved or an object that needs improvement.
This tweet suggests that capitalism offers more career choices and opportunities compared to working in academia or government, which tend to attract more anti-capitalists.

subcategories.name: Social Issues
subcategories.description: Tweets discussing social problems, inequalities, and societal challenges.

subcategories.name: Philosophical Perspectives
subcategories.description: Tweets exploring philosophical ideas, existential questions, and alternative viewpoints.

subcategories.name: Cultural Critiques
subcategories.description: Tweets critiquing or analyzing cultural trends, norms, and societal values.

categories.name: Humor and Satire
categories.description: Tweets with a humorous, satirical, or comedic tone.
examples: This tweet humorously suggests using WWE (World Wrestling Entertainment) Heavyweight Champions as code reviewers, implying that they would be tough and uncompromising critics.
The tweet humorously compares being 31 years old and still actively using Twitter to being a 'super senior' in college - someone who takes longer than the typical 4 years to graduate.
This tweet appears to be a humorous, exaggerated description of someone dual-wielding katanas (Japanese swords) to fight off enemies called 'glazers'.

subcategories.name: Memes and Internet Culture
subcategories.description: Tweets related to internet memes, viral content, and online culture.

subcategories.name: Parody and Satire
subcategories.description: Tweets that parody or satirize popular culture, public figures, or societal trends.

subcategories.name: Observational Humor
subcategories.description: Tweets that find humor in everyday observations and relatable situations.

categories.name: Personal Experiences and Anecdotes
categories.description: Tweets sharing personal stories, experiences, and anecdotes.
examples: This tweet recounts a quote from an experienced venture capitalist who claims that technical knowledge is less important than understanding people when evaluating founders.

This tweet describes a friend's clever tactic for starting conversations on the dating app Hinge. He would reply to every woman's prompt with 'I sense heartbreak...tell me about it', which led them to share their breakup stories with him.
The tweet recounts an early morning conversation with a Lyft driver who shared his philosophical perspective on life.

subcategories.name: Life Lessons
subcategories.description: Tweets sharing valuable life lessons or insights gained from personal experiences.

subcategories.name: Travel and Adventure
subcategories.description: Tweets about travel experiences, adventures, and exploring new places.

subcategories.name: Relationships and Connections
subcategories.description: Tweets discussing personal relationships, social interactions, and human connections.

categories.name: Miscellaneous and Unclear
categories.description: Tweets that are unclear, lack context, or do not fit into other categories.
examples: This tweet consists of the text 'Same' without any additional context or explanation.
This tweet contains three links, but no text or image content. Without being able to access the links or view the image, it is difficult to determine the subject matter or purpose of the tweet.
This tweet consists of the abbreviation 'gm', which stands for 'good morning'. It is a common greeting used on social media platforms, particularly in the crypto and Web3 communities.

rationale: The categorization scheme aims to organize the diverse range of tweet descriptions into meaningful and distinct categories. The categories cover various topics such as AI and technology, business and entrepreneurship, personal growth and mindset, science and research, creative arts and design, social commentary and perspectives, humor and satire, personal experiences and anecdotes, and a miscellaneous category for unclear or unclassifiable tweets. Each category has a description that captures its essence, along with examples from the provided tweet descriptions to illustrate the types of content that would fall under that category. Additionally, subcategories are included for some categories to further refine and organize the content within those broader topics.
usage_tips: Use the category descriptions and examples as a guide to determine the most appropriate category for a given tweet.
If a tweet covers multiple topics, consider the primary or most prominent theme to determine the category.
For tweets that do not fit neatly into any of the defined categories, use the 'Miscellaneous and Unclear' category.
Feel free to suggest additional categories or subcategories if you encounter tweets that do not align well with the existing structure.
Remember that categorization can be subjective, and reasonable people may disagree on the appropriate category for some tweets.
